awd_titl_txt: RAPID/Collaborative Research: Investigation of 2021 Marshall Fire Impacts on Physical Infrastructure and Decision-Making Processes
awd_abstract_narration:
The Marshall Fire on December 30, 2021 greatly impacted the rapidly developing communities of Louisville, Superior, and unincorporated Boulder County. Boulder County adopted voluntary wildfire mitigation in 2011 and spent considerable funds on educating the public about the risks of wildfires. The fire impacted regions with a mixture of older homes (e.g., Original town Superior) and modern homes (built within the last 10-20 years). There is a critical gap in knowledge on how to design, build, and maintain more resilient communities, while balancing the demands of the present with the climate and infrastructure demands of the future. This Grant for Rapid Response Research (RAPID) collaborative project is led by structural, geotechnical, construction, and lifeline engineers, many of whom are cross-trained in social science and policy, to investigate damage patterns to physical infrastructure (buildings, foundations, and retaining structures), and the influence of that damage on decision-making processes for planning and reconstruction. More immediately, the results of this research will inform policies on building regulations in wildland urban interface (WUI) communities.

This research will quantify the impact of building characteristics (year built, building and façade materials, foundation type and characteristics, proximity of other homes, presence/condition of fences or decks, proximity to vegetation) on housing survivability and re-occupancy in wildfires within grassland landscapes. Using the damage patterns and mechanistic behavior of the homes and their various structural components along with understanding of heat transfer and fire spread within a community, the PIs will develop a methodology to quantify exposure temperatures and duration. This data will be used to develop heat maps of the City of Louisville as a method to portray fire intensity throughout the town. These maps can be used by future research teams for benchmarking fire simulations and empirically-designed or validated predictive models. The research will also characterize the jurisdictional reconstruction decision-making processes and tradeoffs in the early post-disaster reconstruction phase.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this RAPID research project is to collect, analyze, understand, and share perishable data related to the 2021 Marshall Fire, which occurred on December 30, 2021 in Boulder County, Colorado. Perishable data collected included uncrewed aerial vehicle (UCAV) imagery, laser scans of damaged infrastructure, and field surveys of individual sites, as well as interviews with public officials and documenting community meetings.  

Conversations with firefighters and 1st responders aided in understanding how, where, and when fire progressed and was contained over the course of the event; which was essential in identifying susceptible community features. Reduced water supply occurred due to water facility damage, the shutdown of the electric grid and natural gas supply (lifelines supporting water treatment and pumping facilities). A comprehensive timeline of events, which we generated from discussions across jurisdictions, aids in differentiating factors impacting structure survivability as well as future emergency response preparations.   

In addition, our team?s attendance at meetings and interviews we conducted captured post-fire rebuilding decisions by jurisdictions.  Jurisdictions grappled with uncertainty regarding costs of recently adopted code requirements while wanting to enable their constituents, many of whom were underinsured, to build and return to their community. Of the three jurisdictions in Boulder County, two created opt-outs for increased energy code requirements; one removed fire sprinkler requirements for all construction, one waived fire sprinkler requirements for rebuilds; while the third kept existing requirements in place and increased ignition requirements for the building code.  Lack of cost certainty and experience with the new codes were reasons for creating opt-outs.  

Statistics related to housing survival data showed that housing arrangement (density and spacing) were important predictors of housing survival. Being in an isolated neighborhood or cul-de-sac was also strongly related to housing loss.  Results also showed that the importance of these variables depended on the jurisdiction, due to differences in the wildland urban interface and building practices in the three communities. This result points to the importance of developing locally-based models to understand wildfire risk. We also found that few of the housing characteristics under homeowner control were critical. Among these factors, the most important factors were related to fencing, decking and exterior resistant cladding and depending on the jurisdiction, but these were less important than the housing arrangement variables. In suburban neighborhoods, because houses are themselves the fuel for the fire, community-wide variables, and community-wide adoption of fire-resistant construction are more critical factors.
